Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Topical Tranexamic Acid in Mastectomy

Background: This study aimed to determine if moistening a surgical wound with tranexamic acid (TXA) before closure reduces postoperative bleeding in mastectomy patients.

Methods: Conducted at St Olav's University Hospital and Ã…lesund Hospital, this two-centre, stratified, parallel-group, placebo-controlled, double-blind randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing mastectomy with or without axillary lymph node clearance. Participants were randomised 1:1 to receive either 25 mg/ml TXA or 0.9% sodium chloride (placebo) before wound closure. The primary outcome was postoperative bleeding measured by drain production in the first 24 hours. Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes. Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors. A sample size of 210 was planned to ensure adequate power.

Results: From January 2016 to August 2018, 208 patients were randomised, with 202 included in the analysis (101 TXA, 101 placebo) using an intention-to-treat approach. TXA significantly reduced mean drain production at 24 hours (110 ml vs. 144 ml; mean difference 34 ml, 95% CI 8 to 60; p = 0.011). Early haematoma occurred in 1 patient in the TXA group versus 7 in the placebo group (OR 0.13, 95% CI 0.02 to 1.07; p = 0.057). No significant differences in other postoperative complications or late seroma aspirations were observed. No thromboembolic events were reported.

Interpretation: Topical TXA before wound closure effectively reduces postoperative bleeding in mastectomy patients, offering a potential alternative to intravenous administration. Trial registration: NCT02627560.

Funding: The study was funded by the involved institutions.
